message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of cyanosis and dyspnea relieved by squatting suggest a cardiac defect that results in right-to-left shunting. Among the options, only ventricular septal defect can cause this type of shunting, leading to cyanosis and dyspnea. Left ventricular hypertrophy and coarctation of the aorta do not typically present with these symptoms, and atrial septal defect usually causes left-to-right shunting.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptom of cyanosis and dyspnea relieved by squatting is characteristic of Tetralogy of Fallot, which includes a ventricular septal defect. Left ventricular hypertrophy and coarctation of the aorta do not typically present with these symptoms, and while an atrial septal defect may cause some cyanosis, it is not typically associated with dyspnea relieved by squatting.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of cyanosis and dyspnea relieved by squatting are consistent with a ventricular septal defect. Left ventricular hypertrophy may cause increased cardiac murmurs, while atrial septal defect and coarctation of the aorta are not associated with squatting relief.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Cyanosis and dyspnea relieved by squatting is suggestive of Tetralogy of Fallot, which includes a ventricular septal defect as one of its components. None of the other answer choices are consistent with this clinical presentation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of cyanosis and dyspnea relieved by squatting are classic signs of a ventricular septal defect. Left ventricular hypertrophy and coarctation of the aorta do not typically present with these symptoms. Atrial septal defect may cause cyanosis but usually does not cause dyspnea relieved by squatting.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest a congenital heart disease, and among the options, only ventricular septal defect can cause cyanosis and dyspnea relieved by squatting. Left ventricular hypertrophy and coarctation of the aorta will not present with cyanosis, and atrial septal defect will not cause dyspnea relieved by squatting.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Cyanosis and dyspnea relieved by squatting are classic symptoms of Tetralogy of Fallot, which includes ventricular septal defect (VSD). The other options do not typically present with these symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options given, only Ventricular Septal Defect (VSD) results in cyanosis and dyspnea relieved by squatting. VSD is a hole in the wall (septum) between the left and right ventricles of the heart, which allows blood to flow between them instead of to the body. This can cause oxygen-poor blood to be pumped to the body, leading to cyanosis (bluish discoloration due to lack of oxygen) and dyspnea (shortness of breath). Squatting increases systemic vascular resistance and decreases pulmonary resistance, leading to more blood flow to the lungs and less shunting of blood through the VSD. This temporarily relieves the symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Cyanosis and dyspnea relieved by squatting suggest a right-to-left shunt, which is most commonly associated with ventricular septal defects. Left ventricular hypertrophy and coarctation of the aorta are not typically associated with a right-to-left shunt. Atrial septal defect may cause a type of shunt, but it is not typically associated with relief of symptoms by squatting.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The combination of cyanosis and dyspnea relieved by squatting suggests a congenital heart defect, and among the options, only a ventricular septal defect (VSD) fits this criteria. VSDs can cause increased blood flow to the lungs, resulting in cyanosis and dyspnea. Left ventricular hypertrophy and coarctation of the aorta would not present with these symptoms, and while an atrial septal defect can cause cyanosis, it would not be relieved by squatting.
